title: Spacetime: is it real and physical, or just a calculational tool?

last_post.content:
Spacetime: is it real and physical, or just a calculational tool?

Matter and energy tells spacetime how to curve, and curved spacetime tells matter and energy how to move.

But we can directly measure matter and energy. Can we say that about spacetime?
https://bigthink.com/starts-with-a-bang/spacetime-real-physical-calculational/

@jonocarroll It kind of helped me to think of the DOM as a giant “excel spread sheet” where each “cell” (HTML Element) _can_ be static, but it can also go away (i.e. have no value in Excel) or be reactive (i.e. code determines the behavior/value). b/c we read static HTML in source files, our (well, *my*) brains trick us into thinking it’s static, but it def isn’t .

Be careful w/ https://www.w3schools.com/xml/dom_namednodemap.asp & https://www.w3schools.com/jsref/dom_obj_html_nodelist.asp due to similar dynamic.

So I said in response to Chris yesterday that it takes a surprisingly long time for people on the fediverse who are ostensibly into decentralization to really 'click' with the power of decentralization. Heres a perfect example.

Why should Mastodon be the next big thing? Mastodon has a very specific culture that a significant group of its users want, and does not lend itself well to scaling. The fediverse should be the next big thing. Just start building a new community on fedi with a different culture, and people who like that culture will come over and that community will grow.

Just let Mastodon have its own specific culture. It does not fit me personally super well either, but I have respect for the people who want it, and I want them to continue having that culture. They deserve that, and it should not be changed for the sake of growth. Let other software grow.

RE: https://mastodon.social/users/arossp/statuses/110307421424312371

I’m running Nodeventure for the first time in 10(!!!) years. It’s a collaborative multiplayer text adventure. It starts off with just a single room and participants are invited to create more. Everything is up for grabs, the code can all be hacked live. For non developers there’s plenty to do, the world we’re creating is largely text with some images, so writers and artists please come!

title: Inside big beef’s climate messaging machine: confuse, defend and downplay

last_post.content:
Great piece in the Guardian revealing the US Beef Industry's heavily-funded strategy to mass engineer public opinion into believing that beef isn't the environmental disaster that it is.

To study their game, the author took their training program, learning how to spread disinformation in the form of 'scientific sounding' arguments on behalf of the industry:

https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/may/03/beef-industry-public-relations-messaging-machine

New blog post looking at #RStats package developer statistics on CRAN: https://tidytales.ca/posts/2023-05-03_r-developers/

I take a stab at answering questions like:

- How many R developers are there?
- How many packages have they contributed to?
- What were their roles?

There’s also an interactive {gt} table in the post, so you can look at your own stats if you have authorship on any CRAN packages, or see who the most prolific authors are.

To avoid procrastination and generate motivation, I'm posting here

For the last 4 years at @opencage we've run a security bounty program, which is rare for a small bootstrapped start-up. It's been interesting.

So my goal for the day is to finally publish a blog post along the lines of "Lessons learned in running a security bounty program as a bootstrapped business".

Let me know if you have any specific questions or comments.

Here's our page describing the program: https://opencagedata.com/security-bounty

@jonocarroll Ah, the joys of dynamic JS DOM objects!

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/HTMLCollection has a decent ‘splainer. TL;DR:

```
An HTMLCollection in the HTML DOM is live; it is automatically updated when the underlying document is changed. For this reason it is a good idea to make a copy (e.g., using Array.from) to iterate over if adding, moving, or removing nodes.
```

https://rud.is/temp/hidden.html has some updated code

PSA for Unity/C# developers: parsing floats is language dependent!

The Green New Deal Simulator had some sneaky bugs changing the effects of certain cards.
Weirdly, they were only reported by people outside the US and UK.

It turns out that by default, on an operating system set to Italian language

float.TryParse("0.5")
returns 5

because of the comma vs dot convention. Same executable, different system settings.
😱😱😱😱😱😱

Well, that was my entire day.

https://devio.wordpress.com/2009/10/15/parsing-culture-invariant-floating-point-numbers/

title: Just Because ChatBots Can’t Think Doesn’t Mean They Can’t Lie

last_post.content:
Better people than me might be able to suppress a chuckle upon discovering that on the very same blog, Professor Cowen recently argued that Francis Bacon was a vehement opponent of the printing press — based on quotations that Bacon never wrote and which appear to have been generated by ChatGPT.

I don't know his GRE scores so I can't comment on their external validity, but given what I do know I can assure you that he's overpaid.

https://www.thenation.com/article/culture/internet-archive-publishers-lawsuit-chatbot/

Around this time last year, the Center for Deep Listening launched A Year of Deep Listening, a call for Deep Listening scores in homage to Pauline Oliveros. I decided to take part, and eventually sent in not one, but ten scores - and then I just kept writing more. (Rather predictably in my case, all of them turned out to be soundwalking scores). I was also very pleased when one of them - Ariadne Soundwalk - was selected for A Year of Deep Listening.

https://acousticmirror.tumblr.com/post/716324720043229184/a-year-of-deep-listening

#PaulineOliveros #DeepListening #Soundwalk #Listening #Scores #CenterForDeepListening

I wish that we were not in a "The Turing Test has already been passed" hype cycle.

You can read Turing's paper. It's not a tough read! https://academic.oup.com/mind/article/LIX/236/433/986238

Some have argued that it's firmly tongue-in-cheek--- but it lays out a fairly unambiguous protocol, and provides concrete examples of how hard it might be for a computer to pass.

1. Human C communicates with Human B over a teletype, and computer A over a teletype, without knowing which is which, but told that one of them is a computer.
2. After a while, C is asked to guess which session is with a human.
3. If C can do no better than 50/50, then A has passed.

Now, this is mainly a thought experiment, not an actual protocol. But note that it's a question about repeated trials, not a single one! Even the Loebner prize went for lightweight versions of the idea. Arguably the Turing test sets the bar _too_ high.

But would ChatGPT or the current generation of chatbots pass? Certainly not. It's not the fairly low bar of "I can't tell if this text was produced by a human or a computer". It's "can you adversarially distinguish between human responses and computer ones in a repeated interaction?"

WebGPU, the new graphics API for JavaScript, shipped in a stable web browser (Chrome 113) about… an hour ago!

I have written a blog post about it, covering a brief (okay, not brief) history of graphics APIs to ~situate WebGPU in a context~, a brief general guide to writing WebGPU, and some specific resources for making WebGPU projects in TypeScript, Rust, and C++ (you can use it on desktop! it doesn't have to be in a browser).

I think WebGPU is really good.
